source.title: Aclar Dishes for Electron Microscope Preparations

source.description:
Wearing gloves, prepare about
in a large weighing boat by combining 10 parts resin with 1 part catalyst (by weight) and stirring extensively with flame-sealed Pasteur pipette. Pour contents into new weighing boat to avoid use of resin without catalyst.

source.title: Sylgard
Aclar Dishes for Electron Microscope Preparations

source.description: Dip an empty 15 ml Falcon tube or glass scintillation vial upside-down into the Sylgard, using it as a rubber stamp to make a circle of Sylgard around the hole, on the outside of the dish.

source.title: Aclar Dishes for Electron Microscope Preparations

source.description: Place the Aclar sheets on the circle of Sylgard, covering the hole.

source.title: Aclar Dishes for Electron Microscope Preparations

).

source.title: Aclar Dishes for Electron Microscope Preparations

To cure the Sylgard, place dishes, upside-down, at
, or at room temperature for 2 to 3 days (cured Sylgard is no longer sticky to the touch).

source.body: Note that these dishes must be coated with laminin before use, just as we do with glass coverslips (see glia dissection protocol)
Left over sylgard from dish preparation can be used to make sylgard circles.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
Drop 100 coverslips (15 x 15 mm) one-at-a-time into a 200 ml beaker containing
. (Leave approx.
at least)

source.title: 95% EtOH
Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
Prepare a solution of poly-d-lysine in “nanopure” or tissue culture grade water. The final concentration should be
and 250mL are adequate for 100 coverslips. Place the poly-Dlysine solution in a glass dish of enough area to give 3/4”/2 cm height to the poly-D lysine solution. (the walls of the dish should be at least 1.5”/4 cm, the area no less than 40”/100 cm square)

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Throw (pour) away excess EtOH. Place ethanol soaked cover slips on to a paper or glass container.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Individually flame dry the coverslips (one pass through flame); use forceps.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
After putting the slip through the flame, allow it to cool in the air in forceps for approximately
while moving back and forth (cracking or sizzling sounds mean it did not cool enough).

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Put the coverslip into the poly-D-lysine solution. Repeat for all slips.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
Let sit for
, then pour off the poly-D-lysine, then let slips dry (
in the hood with the blower on).

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Prepare dishes with 10 mm holes punched with a bench punch for wells where neurons and glia will grow. Sylgard the coverslips to the dishes after the holes are prepared.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
Wearing gloves, prepare about
in a large weighing boat by combining 10 parts resin with 1 part catalyst (by weight) and stirring extensively with flame-sealed Pasteur pipette. Pour contents into new weighing boat to avoid use of resin without catalyst.

source.title: Sylgard
Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Dip an empty 15 ml Falcon tube or glass scintillation vial upside-down into the Sylgard, using it as a rubber stamp to make a circle of Sylgard around the hole. Use caution when applying the Sylgard as too much will result in excess Sylgard covering the culturing surface of the coverslip whereas inadequate Sylgard will result in a leaky well.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Place the coverslips on the circle of Sylgard, covering the hole.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description: Press down on coverslip gently using forceps to eliminate bubbles.

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
Allow Sylgard to spread (about
).

source.title: Glass Coverslip Preparation

source.description:
To cure the Sylgard, place dishes, upside-down, at
, or at room temperature for 2 to 3 days (cured Sylgard is no longer sticky to the touch). Once the dishes are cured they can be stored in zip-lock bags at
until needed.

source.body: Note that these glass coverslips must be coated with laminin before use (see glia dissection protocol
Left over sylgard from dish preparation can be used to make sylgard circles.
If these coverslips ever become unavailable, the Bellco #2 photoetched coverslips have been recommended

source.title: The TechTip Preparation

source.description: Obtain a box of 1000 ul pipette tips (unfiltered). Wear gloves.

source.body: These are used for triturating cells

source.title: The TechTip Preparation

source.description: Flame all tips in order to seal off hole (we recently started using tips without sealing the hole, making additional holes with needles as described below).

source.title: The TechTip Preparation

source.description: Using a needle, poke a hole as close to the tip as possible through one side and out the other. This will result in two holes. The purpose of piercing right through both sides is to prevent cells getting caught in the pipette. Rather, they will have an outlet hole. Make 3 types of tips, with Large (21G 1½), Medium (22G 1½) and Small (26G 1½ ) size holes.

source.title: The TechTip Preparation

source.description: Autoclave as usual.

source.title: Sylgard Circles

source.description: Weigh out the Elastomer Base and the Elastomer Curing Agent. Mix in the ratio 10:1

source.body: For use during dissection as a platform to do the cutting:

source.title: Sylgard Circles

source.description: Mix well and pour into 12 micro well plate, about 3-4 mm in height.

source.title: Sylgard Circles

source.description:
Cure in oven at
for
or at
for 5-7 days.

source.title: Sylgard Circles

source.description: Cut circles out of wells using razor and individually wrap each circle in aluminum foil, autoclave to sterilize.

source.body: Left over sylgard from dish preparation can be used to make sylgard circles.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
LAMININ COATING
Before the dissection/digestion time, dilute 1 aliquot of laminin (140ul of 0.5mg/ml laminin = 70 µg) in
. Final concentration
.

source.title: sterile MEM
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Prepare the papain dissociation solution. Each vial should hold tissue from a maximum of 2 animals though it’s better to digest 1 rat cortex per vial.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Sterilize the top of each Nunc specimen vial (25 ml) with ethanol. Punch two holes in the top with an 18 gauge needle, using a separate needle to bore holes. In one hole place a new needle with a 0.22 µm filter attached. Leave the other hole empty for ventilation.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Add an HCl-cleaned, autoclaved micro-stir bar to the vial. Fill each tube with
-
(sterile filtered with 0.22 µm filter). Place in temperature controlled
water bath with magnetic stirrers.

source.title: freshly made papain solution
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Arrange dissection tools, microscope, dissection light, a bunch of transfer pipettes, sterile Petri dish with Sylgard circle, beaker, and 70% ethanol in a 50 ml tube in the sterile hood.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Prepare two buckets of ice to chill the PBS and for the pups.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Cut aluminum foil squares (about 15 x 15 cm).

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Perfuse dissociation tube (papain tube) with a steady flow of humidified carbogen (95% oxygen, 5% CO2) delivered through the filter/needle (flow rate adjusted to about 1 bubble per second).

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
When the papain has reached a pH of
-
in about
-
(indicated by a red color; purple indicates that the papain solution is too alkaline and orange that it is too acidic), anesthetize pups and begin dissection.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Anesthetize pups with an intraperitoneal injection of ketamine (0.01 and 0.05 ml of 100 mg/ml for mouse and rat pups, respectively).

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: When pups begin to show sedation, put them on ice till hypothermic.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Rinse aluminum foil square, scissors and head with 70% EtOH.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Decapitate pup, allowing head to fall onto aluminum foil square and move to hood.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Remove the olfactory lobes and brain stem (with V-cut). Hemi-sect brain and then peel off meninges. Shell out cortex, taking care to remove the hippocampus. Remove any torn areas to avoid DNA release. Cut into 1 mm3 chunks.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
DIGESTION
Place chunks in papain as with neuronal prep, without kynurenate (1 cortex/vial). Chunks will be digested enough to triturate during the initial
-
. We judge by the appearance of the chunks (like cotton candy) when they are ready.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
DISSECTION
Obtain one or two P1-P3 rats.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Add at least
per round well (enough to cover the surface) for minimum
at
(can be done O/N at +4°C) before plating cells and leave in flow bench. Aspirate off laminin and wash each well with MEM. Place into
incubator to warm dishes before plating the cells. 1 aliquot is enough for about 50-60 dishes.

source.title: 10 µg/mL laminin
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
TRITURATION AND PLATING
Warm up
for rinsing and trituration.

source.title: sterile M10C-G

source.description: From this point forward, everything should be done in a sterile laminar hood with sterile technique.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Remove chunks from enzyme vial using transfer pipette and place in 15 ml conical test tube.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Rinse chunks 3 times using
, allowing them to settle each time and discard supernatant:

source.title: M10C-G
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Using
triturate up to a maximum of 10 times (3-5 times should be sufficient) using a regular 1 ml pipette tip.

source.title: warm M10CG
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Remove supernatant to a separate tube, and replace the volume with
.

source.title: fresh M10C-G
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Repeat trituration using the tech tips with smaller holes each time until the chunks have all fallen apart.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Pellet the glial cells at
.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
. Resuspend pellet in
, and count the cells using hemocytometer

source.title: M10C-G
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Dilute to plating density of 1,000,000-1,500,000 cells/ml.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Remove laminin from wells and plate about 80,000 cells per well. Plate by dripping the cell suspension from about 10 cm above the dish to help minimize number of surviving neurons in glial prep.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Tap the sides of the trays (not for island cultures) in order to evenly distribute cell suspension.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Allow cells to settle for
-
in incubator.

source.body: For island preps allow 2-5 hours.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Chill M10C-G in meantime.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
RINSING AND FEEDING
For monolayers: squirt
into each well, moving the pipette around in a circular motion to wash each well evenly.

source.title: cold MEM
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Aspirate off MEM and repeat wash:

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
For island cultures: One dish at a time, lift the cover and tilt the dish at a 45° angle with the hood countertop. Using a transfer pipette very gently, drip
onto a spot on the dish just above the well so that it slides down the incline and over the well.

source.title: cold MEM
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Aspirate off the MEM.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Feed with
.

source.title: cold M10C-G
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description:
Add FDU to the dishes when cells are ~70% confluent (about 3-5 days). If neurons are still present at this point, remove the medium and cold-feed with
before adding FDU.

source.title: M10C-G
Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Astrocytes dishes should be at least one week old and at most 4 weeks old at the time the neurons are plated. Feed with cold M10C-G at one month if not already used.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Please see "Before Starting" in Guidelines & Warnings section on Things to Prepare during the Week before Plating Glia and Neurons.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
First, turn on the dissociation water bath and let warm to
.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Make the papain dissociation solution (see Media section). Each vial can hold tissue from 1 to maximum 10 mice preps.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Sterilize the top of each Nunc specimen vial with EtOH. Make two holes in the top with an 18 gauge needle, using a separate needle to bore holes. In one hole place a new needle with a 0.22 µm filter attached. Leave the other hole empty for ventilation.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Arrange dissection tools, microscope, dissection light, a bunch of transfer pipettes, sterile Petri dish with sylgard circle, beaker, and 70% ethanol in a 50 ml tube in the sterile hood.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Get 2 buckets of ice to chill the PBS and to anesthetize the pups.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Rip aluminum foil squares (about 15 cm2 ).

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Fill “insulin” syringe with 100 mg/ml ketamine solution.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Obtain as many P1-P3 rat or mouse pups as needed (animals which are one to three days old)

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Superfuse dissociation tube (papain tube) with a steady flow of humidified carbogen delivered through the filter/needle (Flow rate adjusted to about 1 bubble per second).

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
When the papain has reached a pH of
-
in about
-
(indicated by the red color, not too purple, not too orange), anesthetization and dissection of pups can begin.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
DISSECTION
Anesthetize pups with an intraperitoneal injection of ketamine (0.01 ml and 0.05 ml of 100 mg/ml ketamine for mouse and rat pups, respectively).

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: When pups begin to show sedation, put them into ice till hypothermic.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Rinse aluminum foil square, scissors and head with 70% EtOH.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Decapitate pup, allowing head to fall onto aluminum foil square and move to hood.

source.body: Some types of mouse tails (for ex, VMATs) need to be saved for genotyping. Prepare a numbered 1.5ml tube for each mouse. After the mouse has been decapitated, remove the tail using a fresh, sterile razor blade and place tail in numbered tube. Put all tubes on ice during the dissection. After dissection, store tubes in -80°C freezer. Alternatively, number the pups with the marker on their back, cut the tails and genotype the pups before the cultures, and no later than 1- day old. This way the pups with the same genotype can be cultured together rather than individually.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Gently remove brain into ice cold PBS-filled Petri dish as described for glia. With anterior of brain facing left on the SYLGARD® circle (dissection will be described for right handed people) use a fine forceps in the left hand to pin the two hemispheres of the brain to the SYLGARD®. Remove any remaining meninges.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Place the brain, dorsal side down, anterior facing left onto the SYLGARD®. Using forceps, pin the brain to the SYLGARD® to immobilize.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Set the magnetic stirrer on low. Chunks should swirl around in the vial gently.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Digest for approx.
-
or until chunks have fallen apart and look something like cotton candy. Periodically examine the tubes to see if segments are sticking to the stir bars; if so, tap vials to loosen tissue.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
DISH AND MEDIA PREPARATION
On day before dissection, take glia dishes and wash them twice with
:

source.title: cold MEM
Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
After dissection, place tubes containing SF1C for rinsing and triturating in the incubator until ready to triturate so that the pH stays between
and
, and the media is warm.

source.body: The media must be at the correct pH (indicated by the red color) or the neurons may die.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
TRITURATION
From this point forward, everything should be done in a sterile laminar hood with sterile technique.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Remove chunks from enzyme vial using transfer pipette and place in 15 ml conical test tube.

source.body: IMPORTANT: Take great care to prevent bubble formation because bubbles are harmful to neurons. If bubbles occur, aspirate them off.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Rinse chunks 2-3 times using about
warmed to
. After adding SF1C for each wash, flick the tube so that the cells swirl around and shake off the papain. Allow tissue to settle each time and discard as much of the supernatant as possible without exposing cells to air.

source.title: SF1C
Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Triturate in
with large-bore tech-tips a couple of times (when done properly the medium becomes slightly opalescent with dissociated cells).

source.title: room temperature SF1C
Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Repeat the trituration process up to three times with a medium-, then a small-bore tech-tip. The chunks should now be completely dissociated into individual cells.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Centrifuge cells at
.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
ATTACHMENT
After
, cells should have attached to the surface of the well. Remove rings from each well using forceps, which have sterile pipette tips at the end.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Add
to each culture for a final concentration of 10 ng/ml GDNF (see media and solutions section how to prepare GDNF).

source.title: GDNF (200 ng/ml)
NEXT DAY - Mitotic Inhibition

source.description:
The next day inhibit the growth of non-neural cells with 5-fluorodeoxyuridine (FDU). Dilute 1000X stock 1:10 by adding
to
.

source.title: stock
MEM
NEXT DAY - Mitotic Inhibition

source.description:
Media should be changed only when necessary (change of color) – aspirate half the media and add fresh preconditioned (pre-warmed at
).

source.body: Try to avoid this step if possible as neuronal cells are very sensitive to the media exchange.

source.title: NEXT DAY - Mitotic Inhibition

source.description: Disturb cultures as little as possible, avoiding multiple observations (especially in the first 2 days after culturing).

source.title: NEXT DAY - Mitotic Inhibition

source.description: Process cells as needed for the individual experiment (ideally, between 5 days to 2 weeks old).

source.body: If necessary after fixation/immunostaining, the coverslips can be taken off the Petri dish (cut between the glass and Sylgard with a scalpel – careful not to break the glass!!!) and mounted on a glass slide. Alternatively, cells can be cultured on free-floating coverslips, which can be later removed from dishes for the experiments.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Obtain one or two rat or five mouse pups P1-P3.

source.body: Prepare astrocyte cultures in tissue culture flasks (225 cm2 for rat and 75 cm2 for mice cultures)

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Anesthetize pups with an intraperitoneal injection of ketamine.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
When pups begin to show sedation, put them
till hypothermic.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Rinse aluminum foil square, scissors and head with 70% EtOH.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Decapitate pup, allowing head to fall onto aluminum foil square and move to hood.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Remove the olfactory lobes and brain stem (with v-cut).

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
DIGESTION
Place chunks in papain as with neuronal prep, without kynurenate (1 rat cortex/vial, or 5 mouse cortexes/vial). Chunks will be digested enough to triturate during the initial
to
. We judge by the appearance of the chunks (like cotton candy) when they are ready

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
TRITURATION AND PLATING
Warm up sterile M10C-G to
for rinsing and trituration.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Remove chunks from enzyme vial using transfer pipette and place in 15 ml conical test tube

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Rinse chunks 3 times using
, allowing them to settle each time and discard supernatant.

source.title: warm M10C-G
Microglial Culture

source.description:
Using
triturate 5-10 times using just the regular pipette tip.

source.title: warm M10CG
Microglial Culture

source.description: Repeat trituration using the tech-tip with smaller size hole, until the chunks have all fallen apart.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Pellet the glial cells at
.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Transfer cell suspension to tissue culture flask. Use big T-225 flask for rat culture and T-75 flask for mouse culture. The yield from two rat brains is ideal for one T-225 flask. And the yield from 5 mouse brains is ideal for one T-75 flask.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Allow cells to settle for at least
, better leave them
in incubator.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
RINSING AND FEEDING
For astrocyte monolayer remove M10CG from flask and squirt ~
onto the base of upright tissue culture flask.

source.title: cold MEM
Microglial Culture

source.description: Aspirate off MEM and feed with cold M10C-G (30 ml per T-225 flask, or 15ml per T-75 flask), and leave ~2 weeks in the incubator.

source.body: DO NOT ADD FDU TO FLASKS!!!!

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
MICROGLIA ISOLATION
Once the cell layers are stable and you start seeing rounded microglial cells on top of the layers (usually 10-14 d after the cortical culture is plated) and floating in the medium. You should harvest the floating microglia at this time.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Shake the flask with a back-and-forth motion several times to help lift the microglia off.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Collect the fluid in two 15 ml conical tube and centrifuge at
.

source.body: Note that the speed is higher than for regular cells centrifugation, which is normally 1,000rpm.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Remove supernate and GENTLY resuspend the cell pellet in
with regular 1ml pipette tip.

source.title: warm conditioned M10CG
Microglial Culture

source.description: Count cells on hematocytometer to determine appropriate volume for cells density @ 60,000 cells/well on neuronal cultures or 150, 000 cells/well 96 well plates for biochemical assays.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
When plating on neuronal cultures place plastic ring around the well and plate cells in the ring. Remove ring after
.

source.body: PLEASE BE SURE TO REMOVE NEURONAL MEDIA (SFIC) AND REPLACE WITH 2-3 DAY ASTROGLIAL CONDITIONED MEDIA BEFORE PLATING MICROGLIA.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Make the initial cut through the entire brain caudal to the midbrain flexure (right line, Fig 1 in Guidelines section), and the second cut rostral to the flexure, including the caudal aspect of the hypothalamus.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Remove any remaining cortex.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Lay the resulting slice flat on the SYLGARD® with the ventral side facing right, and the dorsal side to the left and the caudal aspect up.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Place the forceps through the aqueduct and push into the SYLGARD® to immobilize the slice.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Cut the ventral edge of the slice along the top of the hypothalamus as indicated by the line in Figure in the Guidelines section.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Cut into 1 mm3 segments and place all three segments into the vial with papain solution for ventral midbrain cultures. For SN cultures only use the two outer segments and for VTA only use the inner segment. Use both SN and VTA for combined VM cultures.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Next cut approximately halfway between the new ventral edge of the slice and the aqueduct.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Replace MEM with
.

source.title: SF1C
Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Leave dishes with SF1C in the incubator
. Alternatively, do this step on the day of the culture, using preconditioned media.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Resuspend the pellet in 0.2-0.5 ml (for mouse cultures) or 1-2 ml (for rat cultures) of media, mix and count (see below).

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description: Add the appropriate volume to the well (into the slide ring) of the SF1C-containing dishes so that each well contains 80,000 cells (use a circular motion to spread the cells around). Again, the rings should ensure that the neurons settle into the well and do not float away or get washed away when moving the dishes.

source.title: Neuronal Preparation on Coverslips with Glia Monolayer

source.description:
Dilute cell suspension until
-
of media contains 80,000 cells.

source.title: NEXT DAY - Mitotic Inhibition

source.description:
Add
to each dish (2 ml media).

source.title: diluted FDU solution
Microglial Culture

source.description: Gently remove brain into ice cold PBS filled Petri dish (with one Sylgard circle – should be covered with cold PBS!).

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Hemi-sect brain and then peel off meninges.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Remove any torn areas to avoid DNA release.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Shell out cortex.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Cut into 1 mm3 chunks.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description: Gently allow the media to swirl around the bottom of the flask to remove unattached cells.

source.title: Microglial Culture

source.description:
Shake additional ~
placing the flask on a shaker at moderate speed.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Using (toothed) forceps hold head by the eyes (using left hand if you are right handed).

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Gently remove brain (using a small scoop shaped scalpel) and place into Petri dish with one SYLGARD® circle stuck onto the bottom and filled with ice cold sterile PBS (use enough PBS such that the brain lying on the SYLGARD® circle is submerged)

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Next, use a micro-scissor to cut around the circumference of the skull, and gently peel the skull off with forceps, being careful in case any tissue still connects it to the rest of the skull.

source.title: Glia Preparation on Coverslip Petri Dishes

source.description: Using the other hand and a curved or angled forceps, pinch the scalp just behind the eyes and pull back, tearing it off.

description: This protocol details the specific steps and media solutions required to dissect and triturate the postnatal netral midbrain dopamine neuronal cultures on mice.
